comment.author: 24469639@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] Not just a hope, but quite likely if you believe in nominative determinism - en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nominative_determinism I worked at Kew Gardens and we had a Gardner, a Redwood ...

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: That rock was a popular spot to sit: L_CAB_02019 from the Lawrence collection. This one and this one from the Indo in 1922 are labelled as the town hall, but I think they are both of this courthouse, too. In the second, you can see the round window in the building opposite over a flat arch, still visible in Google streetview..

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] " Excellent! Rechecked the OSI map, and it says Const. Bk., presumably Constabulary Barracks, so yes, a constable if not quite a policeman yet..."  When is a Constable a policeman and vice versa?  The police in England and other parts of the UK take an oath that they will "blah, blah. blah in the office of Constable!"  The supreme policeman outside the London Met is invariably a "Chief Constable" therefore a constable is a policman/woman while a policeman/woman is not necessarily a constable.  For example the oldest police force in the UK is the London Harbour Police and they are not constables!!!
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] Well done on the quick spot and comment.  I would have known it but got to the game too late!

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] Yep, think you're right - the railings are those of the Courthouse. The Town Hall is a lovely building too...

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: Apologies for absence - I've been out on my bike training for this. Since then I've read about the Tubbercurry Murder Conspiracy (case heard at Sligo), hearings connected with the Woodford case (Dr Tully) and the 1892 murder in Glasgow of a woman named O'Connor, who had been a servant at Sligo Courthouse. According to the Dundee Courier & Argus the constabulary were expecting trouble at Sligo Courthouse for the count of the April 1891 Sligo election.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/15319761@N06] As the gentleman in question is standing outside what was then and still is a police station the presumption is that he is a police officer. The uniform is similar to other police uniforms of that period, for example [www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland/8241200776/in/photostream]
